Menorrhagia and pelvic pain from fibroids (https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/201) - "For women with menorrhagia and pelvic pain from fibroids, consider pelvic ultrasound to assess fibroid size and location." 2. Obesity with BMI 61, hypertension, type 2 diabetes (https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/educational/lose_wt/BMI/bmicalc.htm) - "A BMI of 61 indicates severe obesity." 3. Previous cesarean sections, potential myomectomy (https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/201) - "For women with a history of cesarean sections and symptomatic fibroids, consider myomectomy or endometrial ablation based on ultrasound findings." HTML-formatted clinical note with adjustments based on guidelines: ```html **Summary:** - Age: 39 years old - Presenting complaints: Heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain - BMI: 61 - Three prior pregnancies, all delivered via cesarean section **Body:** Mrs. Smith, a 39-year-old female with a BMI of 61, presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and worsening pelvic pain, impacting her daily life. She has a history of fibroids, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes, with surgical history significant for appendectomy. The clinician recommends a pelvic ultrasound to assess the fibroids' size and location, considering a myomectomy or endometrial ablation due to the severity of symptoms and previous cesarean sections. A physical examination will be performed to rule out other gynecological issues. **Plan:** 1. Schedule pelvic ultrasound to evaluate fibroids. 2. Consider myomectomy or endometrial ablation based on ultrasound findings. 3. Refer to a nutritionist for weight management. 4. Schedule a follow-up appointment to discuss treatment options and address any questions or concerns. ```
